>So said areider on 2003-06-23 --------------------
>Is it true that test m=
ethods must return void in order to be 
>considered a test method? It seems=
 that if a value is returned from a 
>testXXXXX method, it is not included.=
 

In JUnit 3.8.1, I have discovered that such a method still runs as a tes=
t, but its return value is ignored.

>Is there a hard reason why? (ie would=
 it break junit to allow test 
>methods which return values or is it just a=
 convention to make the 
>introspection easier?) 

One simple reason is thi=
s: the framework won't do anything with your return value, so don't bother.=
 It's one these thing to worry about.

>I would like to write test methods =
that I can reuse outside of junit, 
>where I would want to inspect the resu=
lt of the test. Right now I'm 
>faced with writing the methods twice.

Why?=
 Can't you just generate the source code for the corresponding JUnit test?
=

If you have this:

class NonJUnitTestClass {
public int myNonJUnitTest() {=

    return 23;
}
}

then generate this code:

public void testWithJUnit() =
{
    assertEquals(23, new NonJUnitTestClass().myNonJUnitTest());
}

You co=
uld use a properties file or something to make changing the expected value =
easier.
